name: Purchased goods and services
Emissions calculation methodology: Calculated using a Life Cycle Analysis approach covering total footprint of milk production from farm inputs through to farm gate. Using the most recent information available for each country where significant raw milk is collected and the quantity of milk collected for the 2015/2016 season.
explanation: This includes greenhouse gas emissions related to purchasing raw milk from supplying farms in New Zealand, Australia and Latin America. This is estimated to be Fonterra's largest source of Scope 3 emissions from purchased goods and services. Our Life Cycle Analysis considers animal and other farm emissions, brought-in feeds, and land-use changes. The reporting of on-farm GHG emissions is one season behind financial year to allow for completion of a lifecycle analysis (i.e. this data is for 2015/2016 season but we are reporting for FY17). As a specific Life Cycle Analysis for Latin America has not yet been completed the GHG emissions for Latin America have been estimated using the Australian emissions intensity and the actual volume of raw milk collected for Latin America. We have also included here scope 3 emissions arising from purchased goods and services from our small number of farms in New Zealand and China where we havemanagement control. We have not included scope 3 emissions associated with non-milk ingredients or third-party manufacturing.

name: Capital goods
explanation: An estimate of the emissions attributable to capital goods purchased in a reporting year suggest these are less than 0.01% of our Scope 3 emissions and therefore not considered to be material.

name: Fuel-and-energy-related activities
Emissions calculation methodology: This calculation includes transmission and distribution losses for purchased electricity and natural gas in New Zealand, calculated using Scope 3 emission factors from the Guidance for Voluntary Corporate Greenhouse Gas Reporting published by the NZ government. These factors do not account for emissions associated with the extraction, production and transport of the fuels for either direct use or for the production of electricity. This calculation does include indirect emissions attributable to the extraction, production and transport of fossil fuels and fuel burned to generate electricity in Australia, as well as losses in the T and D network. This was calculated using purchased fuel and electricity data and emission factors from the Australian Government's National Greenhouse Accounts Factors.
explanation: Energy transmission and distribution losses have been included for gas and electricity purchases in New Zealand and Australia. These account for 89% of all gas and electricity purchases by energy. Assuming that losses were proportional in other regions this would amount to additional scope 3 losses of less than 0.04% of our total Scope 3 emissions and therefore not considered to be material.

name: Waste generated in operations
explanation: The majority of our solid waste is a by-product of manufacturing practices; for example, packaging, damaged product and personal protective equipment that cannot be reused or recycled. Minimising our solid waste to landfill is a part of our long standing environmental efficiency programme across our NZ manufacturing sites. We aim to reduce this waste to landfill across our global operations. Using the national average emissions factor default value from the NZ Ministry for the Environment Guidance for Voluntary Gas Reporting 2016 and total mixed waste to landfill from our global manufacturing operations we have estimated the total emissions arising from waste to be less than 0.1% of Fonterra's Scope 3 emissions. These are therefore not considered to be material.

name: Business travel
Emissions calculation methodology: Data has been collected and reported for all business travel by air organised through our nominated travel agent, which are estimated to account for more than 95% of Fonterra's total global air travel.
explanation: Travel by air is estimated to dominate our GHG emissions arising from business travel and the calculated emissions account for less than 0.05% of Fonterra’s Scope 3 emissions. These are therefore not considered to be material.

name: Employee commuting
explanation: Fonterra has undertaken an estimation of emissions from employee commuting using national average data from Statistics New Zealand. Employee commuting is estimated to represent approximately 0.1% of Fonterra's Scope 3 emissions and therefore is not considered to be material.

name: Upstream leased assets
explanation: Fonterra does not lease any assets that are not already accounted for in our Scope 1 and 2 emissions.

name: Downstream transportation and distribution
Emissions calculation methodology: Tonnes of carbon from downstream transportation and distribution activities has been calculated for finished goods moved from New Zealand manufacturing sites to port and by ocean freight to final destination port in the world. Movements within New Zealand are based on all product movements (e.g. including to temporary storage warehouses) by road and rail using standard distances and tonne-km factors from New Zealand Ministry of Transport 2014. For ocean freight data, was obtained from our key international transport partner, Kotahi. Actual container movements data and the Clean Cargo Working Group (CCWG) methodology were used to calculate the CO2 emissions.
explanation: Data has been collected and reported for finished goods moved within New Zealand and exported from New Zealand to final destination port in the world only. This is estimated to account for more than 80 per cent of our emissions from distribution of finished goods.

name: Processing of sold products
explanation: The majority of products sold by Fonterra are intermediate products, with many potential downstream applications - Fonterra is therefore unable to reasonably estimate the downstream emissions associated with the various end uses of the intermediate product. As per the guidance contained in the Greenhouse Gas Protocol Corporate Value Chain (Scope 3) Accounting and Reporting Standard, figure 6.4, Fonterra is therefore able to exclude this downstream emission from its report.

name: Use of sold products
explanation: Use of our ingredients products is considered under processing of sold products. Use of our consumer products has been estimated as not material in the context of the life cycle emissions of our products.

name: End of life treatment of sold products
Downstream leased assets
explanation: We do not own downstream assets that are leased to third parties.

name: Franchises
explanation: We have a small number of franchisees in our NZ domestic market but we purchase the electricity for their product storage and this is considered under our scope 2 emissions. The emissions from their transportation activities would be considered under our scope 3 transportation and distribution emissions but has been estimated to be immaterial in this context. There is therefore nothing materially relevant left to report under this category.

name: Investments
explanation: Investing or providing financial services is not a core part of Fonterra's business, therefore this category is not considered to be relevant.
